title.narrative: COVID-19 Strengthening Women’s Ability for the Productive New Opportunities (SWAPNO-II)
COVID-19 Strengthening Women’s Ability for the Productive New Opportunities (SWAPNO-II)

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 Detta projekt syftar till att lyfta några av Bangladeshs fattigaste kvinnor, som lever på landsbygden i delar av landet som är särskilt utsatta för klimatförändringarnas negativa effekter, ut ur extrem fattigdom genom att dra nytta av produktiva inkomstmöjligheter. Den primära målgruppen är 3600 kvinnor i Kurigram, Lalmonirhat, Gaibandha och Jamalpur distrikten även om betydligt fler människor, inklusive dessa kvinnors barn, kommer att dra viss nytta av projektets positiva effekter.
SWAPNO-II syftar till att öka målgruppens inkomster och tillgångar genom att vidga deras valmöjligheter, öka deras kapacitet att göra val, stärka deras motståndskraft mot externa chocker, inklusive klimatrelaterade katastrofer och öka deras tillgång till finansiella tjänster samt se till att projektets fördelar kvarstår över tid.
Målen ska nås genom en kombination av ansträngningar. Kvinnorna anställs först i offentliga arbeten fora att återuppbygga eller klimatsäkra kritisk infrastruktur och för det arbetet får det en liten, men säker lön var fjortonde dag under ett halvår. En del av lönen sparas automatiskt och den delen får kvinnorna tillgång till som en större engångssumma vid anställningsperiodens slut. Meningen är att den ska möjliggöra för kvinnorna att starta sina egna småföretag. Kvinnorna får också utbildning i olika vardagskunskaper och lite yrkeskunskaper som är relevanta för att hitta anställning eller starta eget företag vilket ökar deras nätverk och personliga värdighet. Stöd ges också för tillgång till digitala finansiella tjänster och försäkringar. Idén är att kvinnornas ökade inkomster, kombinerat med ökade kunskaper och självsäkerhet ska hjälpa dem att investera på ett produktivt sätt som ger dem avkastning under kommande år. Dessutom bidar projektet till att öka de lokala myndigheternas kapacitet att implementera fattigdomsreducerande och genderkänsliga sociala transfereringssystem.

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 This project aims at sustainably lifting some of Bangladesh’s poorest women, living in rural areas prone to the negative effects of climate change, of out of extreme poverty, primarily by making use of productive income-generating opportunities. The main beneficiaries are 3600 women in the districts of Kurigram, Lalmonirhat, Gaibandha and Jamalpur even if a substantially larger number of people, including these women’s children, will benefit, to various extents, from the positive effects of this project.
SWAPNO-II aims to increase the targeted women’s income and assets by expanding their choices, enhance their capabilities for exercising choices, strengthen their resilience to shocks, including disasters and climate change, and enhance their financial inclusion and ensure that the benefits are sustainable over time.
This will be achieved through a combination of efforts. The women will first be engaged in public-works to rehabilitate and/or climate proof critical local infrastructure for which they receive a small, predictable, fortnightly, salary during a period of six months. A part of the remuneration is set aside in compulsory savings which the women will access as a lump-sum at the end of the public-works period to allow them to, for example start their own small-scale businesses. They will also be trained in various life-skills as well as skills relevant for future employments, enhancing their networks and contributing to personal dignity. Assistance will also be provided to access digital financial services and insurance schemes. The idea is that their increased income combined with life and employability skills and enhance self-esteem will help beneficiaries invest productively to ensure a stream of income in years to come. Moreover, the capacity of the local government to implement pro-poor, gender-sensitive social-transfer projects will be enhanced.

The extended phase of SWAPNO II proposes utilising different livelihood skill development training, life skill training, engagement with additional income-generating activities and access to different service providing agencies which will lead to the ultimate goal of the project: "Increased productivity as well as profitability, productive employment, and ensured social, economic, and environmental benefits". This will be delivered through three inter-linked outcomes of the project,
Outcome (i): Increased income and assets engaging local economy and skill development,
Outcome (ii): Strengthened human capabilities to build climate resilience capacity, and
Outcome (iii) Strengthen institutional capacity for sustaining SWAPNO benefits.
During the proposed extended phase, SWAPNO II will support another 10,044 underprivileged and climate vulnerable rural women from 10 poorest districts of Northern flood prone areas and Southern Coastal zone of Bangladesh. In addition, the project will provide need-based follow-up support to 3,564 women from the current phase who already graduated from extreme poverty.

tag.narrative: 1.4 - By 2030, ensure that all men and women, in particular the poor and the vulnerable, have equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to basic services, ownership and control over land and other forms of property, inheritance, natural resources, appropriate new technology and financial services, including microfinance.

1.4 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla män och kvinnor, i synnerhet de fattiga och de utsatta, har lika rätt till ekonomiska resurser, tillgång till grundläggande tjänster, möjlighet att äga och kontrollera mark och andra former av egendom samt tillgång till arv, naturresurser, lämplig ny teknik och finansiella tjänster, inklusive mikrokrediter.
12.2 - By 2030, achieve the sustainable management and efficient use of natural resources.
12.2 - Senast 2030 uppnå en hållbar förvaltning och ett effektivt nyttjande av naturresurser.

13.3 - Förbättra utbildningen, medvetenheten och den mänskliga och institutionella kapaciteten vad gäller begränsning av klimatförändringarna, klimatanpassning, begränsning av klimatförändringarnas konsekvenser samt tidig varning.
13.3 - Improve education, awareness-raising and human and institutional capacity on climate change mitigation, adaptation, impact reduction and early warning.
2.1 - By 2030, end hunger and ensure access by all people, in particular the poor and people in vulnerable situations, including infants, to safe, nutritious and sufficient food all year round.

2.1 - Senast 2030 avskaffa hunger och garantera alla människor, i synnerhet de fattiga och människor i utsatta situationer, inklusive små barn, tillgång till tillräckligt med säker och näringsrik mat året om.

5.a - Genomföra reformer för att ge kvinnor lika rätt till ekonomiska resurser, möjlighet att äga och kontrollera mark och andra former av egendom samt tillgång till finansiella tjänster, arv och naturresurser, i enlighet med nationell lagstiftning

5.a - Undertake reforms to give women equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to ownership and control over land and other forms of property, financial services, inheritance and natural resources, in accordance with national laws.
8.1 - Sustain per capita economic growth in accordance with national circumstances and, in particular, at least 7 per cent gross domestic product growth per annum in the least developed countries.
8.1 - Upprätthålla ekonomisk tillväxt per capita i enlighet med nationella förhållanden och i synnerhet en BNP-tillväxt på minst 7 procent per år i de minst utvecklade länderna.

title.narrative: Sustainable Graduation from Exxtreme Poverty of SWAPNO Women Project-II

description.narrative:
SWAPNO is a poverty-reduction project, based on rural and local multi-stakeholder partnerships to strengthen public works and social transfers targeting ultra-poor rural women between 18 to 50 years of age who are widowed, divorced, abandoned, or left with a disabled husband.
The project was initiated in September 2019, and within less than three years it has effectively improved the conditions for the underprivileged beneficiaries to enable them to graduate out of poverty, despite difficulties in obtaining the funding necessary and against the hardships that the global pandemic made out. The Embassy of Sweden, Dhaka, represented by the Swedish International Development Cooperation Agency (Sida), and the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP), entered into a cost-sharing agreement on 05 August 2020 to implement the second phase of the project Strengthening Womens Ability for the Productive New Opportunities (SWAPNO II) in Bangladesh.
With Swedens support, the current phase of SWAPNO has facilitated to graduate 3,564 poor and climate vulnerable women from three climate impacted districts (Jamalpur, Lalmonirhat and Gaibandha), out of extreme poverty and helped them sustain a higher income (5 times higher than baseline). The project has helped these women build their confidence, increase their skills, connect them with informal and formal sectors, link them with services and the local market, and ensure their financial inclusion. This has secured their livelihoods and increased their resilience to shocks and disasters, improved their self-confidence and empowered them for the rest of their lives.
Given the projects successful methodology and applicability to graduate poor out of poverty, and with shown appreciation and acknowledgement from the local and national Government authorities, the SWAPNO team of UNDP wants to extend the project benefits to 10 more of the poorest and most climate-vulnerable districts in the Northern flood-prone areas and in the Southern Coastal zone. Under the proposed extension UNDP wants support another 10,044 underprivileged and climate vulnerable rural women to create access to decent employment, ensure a discrimination-free environment in public workplaces, develop adaptive livelihoods, establish localized cottages, small and medium enterprises (CSMEs), and to provide access to financial services for sustainable graduation from extreme poverty. In addition, the project will provide needs-based follow-up support to 3,564 women from the current phase of SWAPNO II who are already graduated from extreme poverty.
SWAPNO is implemented by the Local Government Division (LGD) and UNDP under the auspices of National Social Security Strategy (NSSS) of the Government of Bangladesh. The overall objective is Economic growth achieved in a more inclusive manner, with economic opportunities reaching rural poor women, and vulnerable groups are protected against shocks.
For Sweden, the proposed contribution is directly aligned with Swedens development cooperation strategy 2021-2025 for Bangladesh, especially for the support area Inclusive Economic Development under its objective "Greater opportunities for productive employment with decent working conditions". The contribution is also in line with support area Climate and Environment and contribute to the objective 2.1: "Limited climate impact and enhanced resilience to climate change and natural disasters". Within the support area of Human Rights, Democracy, the Rule of Law and Gender Equality, SWAPNO will contribute to objective 1.3: Better prospects for a gender-equal society. In the support area Health including sexual and reproductive rights, SWAPNO will make a small contribution to objective 4.1: Enhanced capacity to provide high-quality health and medical care.
The proposed project also aligns with core strategies underpinning United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework (UNSDCF) 2022-2026 for Bangladesh. It contributes directly to UNSDCF Strategic Priority Area 1: Inclusive and Sustainable Economic Development and Strategic Priority Area 3: Sustainable, Healthy and Resilient Environment
Conclusively, the appraisal team at the Embassy of Sweden in Dhaka assesses that the extension and enlargement is relevant and would increase the positive effects of the project, and it also in alignment with and contributing to national priorities and multi-lateral strategic frameworks.
The Embassy also proposes some follow-up issues as of below:
- Monitoring the systemic change: The Embassy will follow-up on how SWAPNO adapts and responds to contextual changes, and what they plan to mesure (indicators) and how in regards to the developmental impacts in the market system that can be derived and attributable to the work in the project.
- Exist Strategy: This is one of the most important issues to follow-up during the implementation of the SWAPNO project, namely how Government of Bangladesh and its' relevant ministries gradually take ownership of the poverty graduation model and continue after the project ends.
- Beneficiary selection: The Embassy has noted that, during the previous phases of the project, 95 percent of the beneficiaries have been selected correctly, according to the project's criteria. The Embassy will follow-up how the project's management intends to improve its performance to increase the share of correctly targeted beneficiaries in the extended phase.
- Partner selection: during the proposed extended phase, SWAPNO is going to extend its support to 10 districts and also recruit new implementing partners (local NGOs) to help the implementation. How SWAPNO efficiently recruits new implementing partners and orient them is also something that need to be followed-up.
- Private sector engagement: In addition, the Embassy will follow-up how efficiently the project brings in private sector partners to assist in the implementation of the interventions, especially with business development services and employment creation.
With this amendment Sweden will contribute with an additional 50 million SEK for extended implementation of the second phase of the Strengthening Womens Ability for the Productive New Opportunities (SWAPNO II) project in Bangladesh, for an additional 36 months (up until June 2025). Sweden's contribution to date is 33.37 million SEK and with the additional 50 million SEK, the total Swedish contribution will amount to 83.37 million SEK.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
